entry.title: Lie Kiat Teng (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Lie Kiat Teng (pictured) appealed to the "moral obligation" of doctors to address a healthcare crisis in South Sulawesi?

entry.title: Democratic Yemeni Union of Peasants (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in 1978 the chairman of the Democratic Yemeni Union of Peasants was arrested after the South Yemeni government was taken over by Abdul Fattah Ismail?

entry.title: Lyle Bauer (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Lyle Bauer continued to attend Canadian Football League executive meetings despite being unable to speak due to his treatment for stage four throat cancer?

entry.title: Capitolium of Constantinople (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Capitolium of Constantinople, originally a pagan temple, was later topped by a cross?

entry.title: 6:16 in LA (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the diss track "6:16 in LA", directed at Drake, samples Al Green's "What a Wonderful Thing Love Is", a song that features Drake's guitarist uncle?

entry.title: Alexander Helfgot (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that an essay of jailed Socialist Revolutionary politician Alexander Helfgot was smuggled out of Russia and published in Berlin in 1922?

entry.title: Terror Train (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that when producer Daniel Grodnik proposed the idea for Terror Train to his wife, she thought that it sounded terrible?

entry.title: Eurovision Song Contest 1991 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Eurovision Song Contest 1991 was moved to Rome from Sanremo at a late stage due to increased security concerns resulting from the Gulf War?

entry.title: Jarrett Kingston (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in college, football player Jarrett Kingston started at the position of left guard, then moved to left tackle, and then played right tackle and right guard?
